title: Episode 20 – Christine Robinson – Deloitte & Touche, Sustainability Services Group
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[8.8s - 14.4s]: Welcome to the Why on Earth Communities Stewardship and Sustainability Podcast Series.

[15.1s - 22.1s]: Today I'm so happy and excited that we are speaking with Christine Robinson from Deloitte,

[22.3s - 22.8s]: Hi Christine.

[23.5s - 24.3s]: Hey, Erin, how are you?

[24.7s - 25.0s]: Great.

[25.2s - 25.5s]: How you doing?

[25.8s - 26.4s]: Good.

[26.4s - 34.6s]: So Christine is with a she is the senior manager in the sustainability services practice

[34.6s - 40.1s]: group at Deloitte and she helps companies with their sustainability reporting initiative

[40.9s - 44.0s]: to drive value and help build a brighter future.

[44.6s - 51.5s]: For some of you who may not be completely familiar with this means, environmental, social

[51.5s - 58.2s]: and governance or ESG risks continue to move up on the board agenda as shareholders,

[58.7s - 65.1s]: regulators, employees and consumers increase pressure on companies to demonstrate responsible

[65.1s - 72.5s]: governance around these risks and address those operational and reputational concerns that

[72.5s - 77.2s]: can have a material impact on the long-term sustainability and financial performance of

[77.2s - 77.8s]: a company.

[77.8s - 84.5s]: And what's so interesting to me, Christine, is that as we're building and developing our

[84.5s - 89.7s]: understanding of sustainability as a community generally speaking and broadly speaking,

[90.7s - 95.4s]: where you're positioned working with all these different companies in the economy, you

[95.4s - 99.8s]: have a very interesting and particular view of what's happening.

[100.3s - 105.7s]: And I thought I might start by asking what from your perspective, what is driving the

[105.7s - 108.2s]: corporate sustainability agenda right now?

[109.0s - 113.7s]: Well, that's a really good questionnaire and there's a lot of things.

[113.7s - 117.2s]: I think most notably right now, it's investors.

[118.9s - 124.6s]: Investors are increasingly relying on sustainability information in their decision-making processes.

[126.1s - 131.6s]: They've voiced frustration by the lack of consistent comparable disclosure.

[132.6s - 141.2s]: There's a number of investors that have specific impact investing funds or other sustainability

[141.2s - 144.6s]: related investment funds and that trend is growing.

[146.3s - 155.2s]: We've also seen pressure from shareholders that may not own a direct share but own through

[155.2s - 163.4s]: like an exchange-traded fund or some funds similar to that where they'll use their proxy

[163.4s - 172.6s]: vote as a way to voice their opinion and their concerns with a company's ESG performance.

[174.2s - 180.6s]: We see particularly a lot of attention given to the ESG Raiders out there.

[180.6s - 186.9s]: So like MSCI, it's seen a litix, ISS, CSR Hub.

[187.7s - 196.6s]: These are organizations that are taking companies, environmental and social performance and governance

[196.6s - 204.5s]: practices and basically putting out a report card on companies so that there's ratings

[204.5s - 207.3s]: out there and companies can be compared to one another.

[207.3s - 214.1s]: I think it really gets the attention of a lot of executives because I'm not sure that

[214.1s - 217.9s]: many realize that that's out there and then all of a sudden they become aware of,

[218.0s - 224.4s]: hey, some of these putting a report card out on my company but I got to know what that is

[224.4s - 227.9s]: and what's the grounds for that score.

[229.2s - 236.8s]: We see a lot of companies also getting questions from their customers.

[237.8s - 249.6s]: Supply Chain is a very, very vast and broad thing and companies now are looking for more transparency

[249.6s - 253.1s]: in their supply chains and so customers are putting the pressure on.

[253.7s - 262.5s]: Particularly I would say you get a lot by the way of European companies where they are,

[262.7s - 268.0s]: they're a little bit more advanced in this space because it's been something that's been reported

[268.0s - 270.4s]: and companies have been doing it for longer there.

[273.2s - 277.0s]: So they're just a bit more mature, I would say.

[277.5s - 283.6s]: And now they're really raising the bar in terms of setting expectations for their customers

[283.6s - 289.8s]: and what they expect in terms of environmental, social governance performance.

[291.2s - 296.7s]: We also see the trends, I think you've probably heard a lot about the millennials

[297.6s - 305.0s]: and the Gen Z generation but as consumers, their buying habits are a lot different than the

[305.0s - 312.7s]: generations before them and the studies of surveys have showed that millennials are aligning their

[313.3s - 319.1s]: purchasing power and their buying habits to their environmental and social beliefs too.

[319.4s - 326.2s]: And so that's a more, I would say, more consumer facing companies feel that pressure.

[327.5s - 334.9s]: And then lastly, I'm going to throw out regulation certainly here in the US,

[335.4s - 341.5s]: any sort of strict regulation might be off the table with the current administration.

[342.3s - 351.2s]: But you see states like California that have moved in the direction of regulation for environmental

[351.2s - 359.6s]: reasons also I think significantly in the EU, the European Union's non-financial reporting

[359.6s - 367.4s]: directive that recently went into effect that requires certain companies to report this information.

[369.3s - 377.9s]: So there's a lot of drivers in this space and I think you could ask a lot of companies that are

[378.3s - 387.1s]: in the market and you might find the various degree of answers in terms of why they're doing it or how they're doing it.

[387.3s - 394.1s]: But at this point, I think it's really, these are business issues that companies have to face and

[395.2s - 400.3s]: more and more of that's being recognized and companies don't want to be caught flat-footed

[401.0s - 406.5s]: when looking at the risks and opportunities that relate to these topics.

[407.3s - 412.7s]: Yeah, it's so interesting. I think it's such an exciting time to be alive and to be able to

[412.7s - 418.8s]: witness this transformation that's occurring. And you know, one of the things I end up thinking

[418.8s - 428.0s]: often about and talking some about is that sustainability really isn't only about us choosing to do good

[428.8s - 432.8s]: relative to our communities, relative to the environment and so forth, but it is

[432.8s - 437.7s]: increasingly becoming a question of competitive advantage. Oh, for sure.

[437.9s - 442.3s]: Heidi of Industries, right? And as consumers are putting more and more pressure on as you're

[442.3s - 449.9s]: describing as we're entering this age of increasing transparency, I am just so thrilled to know that

[449.9s - 456.4s]: there is rapid transformation underway. And I'm curious, you're working with some of the

[456.4s - 463.7s]: largest companies in the world, many mid-size mid-cap companies. What does that look like from your

[463.7s - 473.0s]: vantage point right now? That's a good question. I would say it looks a lot like the Wild West.

[475.2s - 482.7s]: As I said, absent any regulation anywhere outside of the EU's regulation.

[483.3s - 491.1s]: Companies at this point right now in terms of reporting and disclosure can do really whatever they want.

[492.2s - 498.9s]: I mean, there's no regulation in terms of what they have to report and how they have to report it.

[500.4s - 512.6s]: There is, and there has been existing sustainability reporting standards. The Global

[513.4s - 520.4s]: they've been around since the early 90s and it's the most widely used set of standards globally.

[521.8s - 528.9s]: Used by many companies, I think there is a statistic out there that says at least in the US,

[529.5s - 538.5s]: 85% of the S&P 500 issue is sustainability report. The majority of those reports are in accordance with

[538.5s - 546.6s]: the GRI standards. Additionally, just this month, yeah, we're still in November.

[547.2s - 554.7s]: The sustainability accounting standards board just codified their standards. And they're

[554.7s - 562.2s]: a bit different from GRI. So GRI standards are applicable to a very broad stakeholder group,

[562.2s - 570.0s]: investors, customers, consumers, shareholders, employees, non-governmental organizations.

[571.8s - 579.7s]: They're not necessarily industry specific. So, SASB, I think it was starting in about 2012,

[579.7s - 586.8s]: undertook this mission to develop industry specific standards on the premise of financial

[586.8s - 595.6s]: materiality. And with the idea and mind that these issues affect companies in a different manner.

[596.7s - 603.5s]: For example, I always like to use the automotive industry as an example because when you talk about

[604.1s - 615.9s]: GHG emissions, the biggest impact for automotive companies in particular is the use phase emissions.

[615.9s - 624.5s]: So you and I driving around in our car versus a different manufacturer where they're not

[625.2s - 630.7s]: their product is different and doesn't have the use phase emissions that automobiles do.

[631.4s - 639.1s]: The SASB standards contemplate that. The SASB standards are specific to investors.

[640.1s - 647.5s]: They're based on the concept of financial materiality. And so by disclosing these industry specific

[647.5s - 657.5s]: standards, investors have a way to connect the ESG to the financial statements a little bit more

[657.5s - 662.0s]: directly and kind of look at what is financially material.

[663.7s - 669.0s]: That's really interesting. Well, I now have to ask, I should mention to your comments about

[669.1s - 673.6s]: its November. So it's November while recording, but this may likely.

[673.7s - 678.8s]: Oh, right. Okay. I guess December of 2018. So speaking of time travel,

[679.9s - 687.5s]: I am struck when I'm building financial models for consulting clients and sometimes even

[687.5s - 694.6s]: educating and tutoring business students around accounting. This is a very particular system.

[694.6s - 703.2s]: You know, thanks to the Renaissance Italian merchant years ago. And it's a system that has evolved

[703.2s - 710.4s]: to be very sophisticated, very specific in its application, which is now really used worldwide.

[711.3s - 717.7s]: And it was developed initially and it has been used for centuries for financial

[718.8s - 724.0s]: reporting and accounting specifically and has not been designed to take into account these other

[724.0s - 729.8s]: things we would consider such as impacts on social well-being, impacts on environmental ecological

[729.8s - 738.5s]: services, so on and so forth. And I have to ask you as you being a CPA, how does this leave you

[738.5s - 744.9s]: after investing years and years in learning this sophisticated language and system?

[745.6s - 751.2s]: How does this leave you feeling and thinking as the endeavor now is to incorporate more

[751.2s - 756.1s]: information that is outside of the financial system strictly speaking?

[757.0s - 763.4s]: No, that's another another great question and really, you know, if you look at the evolution

[763.4s - 770.3s]: of financial accounting, it was an evolution. And I think that's what this is too. You know,

[770.3s - 777.7s]: you have this is information that's out there in the public domain. And I always tell people that

[777.7s - 783.5s]: really I spent eight years in the financial statement audit practice within the late before moving

[783.5s - 790.1s]: into sustainability. And I always I look back on that time and I kind of take for granted my role

[790.1s - 795.1s]: as the auditor because the systems were so established and the financial accounting rules are so

[795.1s - 802.9s]: established and there's socks 404 and controls and you know everything was just very mature and

[804.2s - 812.4s]: robust. And then you come into sustainability where you have companies with the ability to disclose

[812.4s - 818.6s]: whatever they want, whenever they want, however they want. You know, there's for example, there's

[818.6s - 823.8s]: even companies out there that they don't report in accordance with GRI or SASB. They'll make up their

[823.8s - 833.5s]: own definition and report that definition. And and that's okay as long as the consumer of that

[833.5s - 840.7s]: information has that definition. But I but I still think and you know, maybe this is the the auditor

[840.7s - 848.5s]: in me coming out and and shining. But because this information is relied upon in the marketplace,

[848.5s - 855.9s]: that it's it just speaks to the case for assurance and you know putting in place companies putting

[855.9s - 863.7s]: in place those credible reporting processes and in controls specific to this subject matter and

[864.4s - 871.6s]: engaging their financial statement auditor to perform assurance on this information. It's I think

[871.6s - 878.0s]: critical in terms of where the market is at right now. There are many companies that do seek

[878.0s - 885.8s]: assurance on maybe I'd say more so specific key performance indicators like most notably greenhouse

[885.8s - 893.6s]: gas emissions. But not necessarily everything that they're reporting or their sustainability report

[893.6s - 900.6s]: as a whole. And I think as this as this space matures and the reporting matures and the disclosure

[900.6s - 908.9s]: matures, then we'll see the assurance of that follow as well. Yeah, it's really interesting to hear

[908.9s - 917.1s]: that perspective. And one of the things I'm struck by in your earlier comment is the incredible

[917.1s - 922.7s]: disparity that we're seeing state to state here in the United States with respect to regulation,

[922.7s - 928.4s]: regulation, standard, and expectations. And it leaves me wondering you know on the on the one hand

[928.4s - 936.6s]: many of these issues are related to risk obviously. And on the other hand many of these issues

[936.6s - 943.8s]: are related to competitive advantage and economic development. And it leaves me thinking that you know

[943.8s - 950.7s]: in some of the region, some of the states that are not really leading that are not really being

[950.7s - 955.5s]: proactive around these issues. They're doing a double disservice to their communities potentially

[955.5s - 962.3s]: where on the one hand, they're not addressing some of these risks we're facing as robustly as they

[962.3s - 967.7s]: could be. And on the other hand, they're not driving the innovation in the laying the groundwork

[967.7s - 973.0s]: for the competitive advantage and the eventual economic development that will ensue. And I'm just

[973.0s - 979.5s]: curious if as you're looking at different firms all around the country, if you get a sense that

[980.7s - 988.0s]: we're really seeing a situation where the ingredients for success over time are much more heavily

[988.0s - 997.7s]: concentrated in certain areas and less so in other areas. There's definitely, I'd say an appetite

[997.7s - 1005.1s]: for innovation. And that's where I think the companies that are doing this whole space,

[1005.1s - 1011.2s]: this whole sustainability thing, the ones that are doing it really right are the ones that are

[1011.2s - 1023.2s]: the innovators and the ones that are able to take a downturn in the economy and gain market share.

[1024.0s - 1033.9s]: Or do some really cool things in research and development and change their products such that it's

[1035.2s - 1043.4s]: somehow game changing for the industry. There's a TED talk and it's a few years, probably at

[1043.4s - 1048.9s]: least 10 years old now. Ray Anderson, the CEO of Interface Carpets, did this TED talk. It was called

[1048.9s - 1059.2s]: the Business Logic for Sustainability. And in the TED talk, he takes you through the journey of

[1059.2s - 1066.2s]: the company's sustainability thinking. And at one point in the TED talk, it pulls up a chart

[1066.8s - 1073.0s]: and shows the economy and how the economy was moving. And there was this little dip in the economy.

[1073.2s - 1079.6s]: And I think it was around 2000. But how his company was actually able to gain market share during that

[1079.6s - 1086.4s]: time because of the way that they innovated their product and the sustainability trends that they

[1086.4s - 1093.0s]: paid attention to and the things that they did in that respect. I think this is going to be

[1093.8s - 1100.9s]: huge in the next 10 years. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change just issued a report

[1100.9s - 1109.1s]: about a month or two ago now. And basically, it said that this climate change is worse than we thought.

[1109.8s - 1115.9s]: And we're going to start seeing the impacts of climate change and a lot sooner than we thought.

[1116.2s - 1122.9s]: So I think they mentioned like 2030 versus I think the previous reports were 2040 or 2050.

[1124.5s - 1132.6s]: But then you start thinking, I'm like, gosh, well, I'm going to be around in 2030. And my kids

[1132.6s - 1140.0s]: will definitely be around in 2030. And I think once businesses start maybe paying attention to that

[1140.0s - 1144.7s]: a little bit more, they're going to recognize it's a little bit more sudden than expected. And

[1144.7s - 1150.6s]: you know, kind of anticipating that through scenario analysis and risk planning. It's going to

[1150.6s - 1159.9s]: give them a leg up when we do start seeing real climate change affecting our day to day lives.

[1159.9s - 1165.7s]: And yes, yeah. And I think, you know, some of our friends who have experienced

[1166.7s - 1173.7s]: coastal flooding and massive forest fires might already be feeling some of the early

[1174.6s - 1179.1s]: of this climate change. And certainly the scientific community seems to be

[1179.7s - 1185.0s]: pointing in that direction as well. And you know, I'm so happy you mentioned that,

[1185.8s - 1195.5s]: that you have kids. And I love that in addition to being a sustainability professional, a CPA,

[1195.7s - 1202.6s]: an accountant, you're also a mom. And you have two young children. And I'm curious as you're,

[1202.9s - 1208.7s]: you know, working by day with all of these different companies that are in varying stages of

[1208.7s - 1215.0s]: addressing and incorporating these sustainability values and standards. When you get home,

[1215.9s - 1224.0s]: what is that like for you? And how do you see some of the sustainability opportunities or challenges

[1224.0s - 1230.7s]: even on the home front? Well, I'll say this. I've already apologized to both of my sons

[1231.9s - 1239.7s]: because the challenges that they'll face in their adult life in particular are much different

[1239.7s - 1246.2s]: than the challenges that, you know, eye faces in adult particular when, you know, we start seeing

[1246.2s - 1251.0s]: the impacts of climate change and, you know, that leading to food scarcity and things and things

[1251.0s - 1261.2s]: like that. And I, as a parent, just have innate anxiety about that and, and hope that they will have

[1261.2s - 1269.7s]: the answer. I've also started to brainwash them, if you will. If you ask my five-year-old son,

[1270.0s - 1278.5s]: what water is, he'll tell you it's a scarce natural resource. And then, you know, I just try

[1278.5s - 1284.7s]: in our everyday lives to do things and so that they're normal to my kids. For example,

[1285.7s - 1293.9s]: both of my, both of my boys were in cloth diapers. We shovel our driveway instead of using a

[1293.9s - 1300.4s]: snow blower. And in southeastern Wisconsin, that's quite a feat. Just earlier this week, I was

[1300.4s - 1306.0s]: I was out in my driveway for four hours with the shovel after after a snow storm, but

[1306.9s - 1314.9s]: we also have hobbies like I'm a beekeeper. I feel a couple of bee hives with my brother and have

[1314.9s - 1323.1s]: like, have done, gotten him into that and, and my mom. And so that's a nice family activity and

[1323.1s - 1331.9s]: something I feel strongly about. I have my kids, you know, all of this to my kids is just

[1332.7s - 1338.4s]: something that's that they've grown up with and something that's normal. And I recognize that

[1338.4s - 1345.6s]: society will start changing them the more and more that they are out of my purview and into

[1345.6s - 1351.0s]: like school when they spend so much time with school and their friends. And so I'm trying now,

[1351.1s - 1357.2s]: while they're really, really young to to put my influence on them that this is something that's

[1357.2s - 1361.2s]: super important and something that they're going to they're going to be challenged with as

[1361.8s - 1368.7s]: they grow into adults. So yes, well, it's so it's so wonderful how proactive you're being with them

[1368.7s - 1375.1s]: and that you're not only on the one hand teaching them about things like water, fresh water being a

[1375.1s - 1380.5s]: scarce and precious resource. On the other hand, you're demonstrating ways that we can be proactive

[1380.5s - 1387.1s]: in our own homes, our own yards, our own neighborhoods. And of course, with the why on earth community,

[1387.2s - 1392.9s]: we are increasingly doing work all around the country with some of the very hopeful activities we

[1392.9s - 1399.5s]: can do such as soil building, which really can help to reverse the climate change trends,

[1399.6s - 1407.3s]: really help to stabilize climate by sequestering carbon. And my sincere hope is that our kids and

[1408.0s - 1415.3s]: all of us in the next several years and decades are going to engage deeply in some of these restorative

[1415.3s - 1421.7s]: and regenerative practices. And my sense is that we'll see companies small medium and large,

[1422.0s - 1429.2s]: increasingly engaging in some of these community activities as a way to market and advertise and

[1429.2s - 1435.9s]: you know, live streaming media has become very big. And I'm just I'm thrilled to think that we can

[1435.9s - 1442.8s]: really mobilize so much hope and the business community can take such a strong leadership position

[1442.8s - 1447.7s]: around all of this. And as we're facing these challenges, they can be overwhelming and daunting.

[1448.3s - 1454.2s]: There yeah, there are you know, to that point, there are so many companies out there that do a lot

[1454.8s - 1462.1s]: and and make a really big impact. And unfortunately, they don't they don't tell that story, they don't

[1462.2s - 1468.7s]: say that. And and that's I feel one of the really cool parts of my job is I get to go into

[1469.5s - 1475.2s]: into all of these different companies and all of these in different industries. And I get to hear

[1475.2s - 1482.8s]: about everything they're doing and it and it really gives me makes me feel optimistic in a

[1482.8s - 1490.3s]: in a time when it's very easy not to be optimistic. Just some of the cool things that are being done

[1490.3s - 1495.4s]: and the things that exist out there and how they're how they're innovating and what they're

[1495.4s - 1503.9s]: doing to address, you know, challenges like soil degradation and erosion and anything waste.

[1504.5s - 1510.5s]: And so that's it's really refreshing. So there's a there's a lot more that I think that's being done

[1510.5s - 1518.2s]: that's just not out there in in the public. And I wish I wish companies would some would sometimes

[1518.2s - 1526.3s]: tell tell those really cool stories. But you know, my sense is that we might be seeing a whole

[1526.3s - 1531.7s]: lot more of that. And I often joke with my media partner, Artem Nicolcov from Earth Coast Productions

[1531.7s - 1540.2s]: about how sometimes the the letters CSO stand for Chief Sustainability Officer and sometimes they

[1540.2s - 1546.9s]: stand for Chief Streaming Officer. We talk often about how we're seeing this convergence where

[1546.9s - 1552.4s]: companies of all sizes can increasingly share these stories, tell these stories and of course that's

[1552.4s - 1557.7s]: very potent in social media. It's very potent in some of the new ways of marketing and advertising

[1557.7s - 1565.7s]: and messaging. And my goodness, that could be such a potent additional way to mobilize this kind

[1565.7s - 1571.4s]: of positive action in our communities all over and that gives me hope. Yeah, and I think you'll see

[1571.4s - 1578.7s]: that. You know, you've got the millennial generation now getting older and sort of creeping

[1578.7s - 1585.2s]: their way into upper management. And this is just this is just the millennial thinking and this is

[1585.2s - 1590.9s]: how they do business. And that's that's different from previous generations. And so I definitely think

[1590.9s - 1601.6s]: those those facets of their lives is going to be it's going to be really apparent when you start

[1601.6s - 1609.2s]: seeing them as CEOs and executives and board members. You know, the board plays a huge role in this.

[1609.6s - 1619.4s]: And I would say a lot of boards might be a bit skeptical at first, but just as in it isn't

[1619.4s - 1625.1s]: anything, I think once you learn more of the subject matter and in what this is all about, it just

[1625.8s - 1634.0s]: the dollars and cents just makes sense. Absolutely. I want to pick up your comment about the

[1634.0s - 1640.0s]: boards and ask you about a recent article you co-authored before asking that question, though,

[1640.0s - 1646.0s]: I just want to mention to our audience that this is the why on earth communities stewardship and

[1646.0s - 1653.6s]: sustainability podcast series. And today we are speaking with Christine Robinson, CPA accountant

[1654.2s - 1662.1s]: and sustainability senior manager at Deloitte. And for those of you who might like to check out

[1662.1s - 1670.2s]: some of our audio book and ebook resources at why on earth.org, be sure to use the code podcast

[1670.2s - 1677.8s]: to get a discount on those. And you might just think about getting something like that in time

[1677.8s - 1683.8s]: for the holidays. We think this this particular episode will be airing in early December. So

[1684.9s - 1691.2s]: that's a great opportunity for you. And you know, we are talking about sustainability as it

[1692.0s - 1700.4s]: appears in the realm of accounting and in the corporate world. And Christine you co-authored

[1700.4s - 1707.1s]: this article, which is called Why Sustainability as a Board-Level Risk. This was in the FO Journal

[1707.1s - 1713.4s]: part of the Wall Street Journal back in July of 2018. And it was it was such a compelling

[1714.3s - 1722.3s]: presentation of some of this information where this really is not a kind of side optional

[1722.3s - 1729.8s]: consideration for boards any longer. This is now a central and increasingly important concern

[1729.8s - 1737.5s]: for boards on companies of all sizes. And I'm curious how has the the reception been to this

[1737.5s - 1741.3s]: this article so far? What are you hearing from your clients and your colleagues?

[1742.4s - 1751.6s]: I think it's gotten tremendous attention actually. I think the you know oftentimes we think about

[1752.2s - 1758.4s]: companies as what's in the four walls and what's inside. And that often doesn't that doesn't

[1758.4s - 1766.8s]: extend to the board. But they play a critical role as more and more

[1768.1s - 1775.2s]: particularly in where we are in this world in terms of climate change. The the measurement

[1775.2s - 1783.1s]: and disclosure of sustainability risks are our key and boards can help provide insight on how

segments.text: Welcome to the Why on Earth Communities Stewardship and Sustainability Podcast Series.
Today I'm so happy and excited that we are speaking with Christine Robinson from Deloitte,
Hi Christine.
Hey, Erin, how are you?
Great.
How you doing?
Good.
So Christine is with a she is the senior manager in the sustainability services practice
group at Deloitte and she helps companies with their sustainability reporting initiative
to drive value and help build a brighter future.
For some of you who may not be completely familiar with this means, environmental, social
and governance or ESG risks continue to move up on the board agenda as shareholders,
regulators, employees and consumers increase pressure on companies to demonstrate responsible
governance around these risks and address those operational and reputational concerns that
can have a material impact on the long-term sustainability and financial performance of
a company.
And what's so interesting to me, Christine, is that as we're building and developing our
understanding of sustainability as a community generally speaking and broadly speaking,
where you're positioned working with all these different companies in the economy, you
have a very interesting and particular view of what's happening.
And I thought I might start by asking what from your perspective, what is driving the
corporate sustainability agenda right now?
Well, that's a really good questionnaire and there's a lot of things.
I think most notably right now, it's investors.
Investors are increasingly relying on sustainability information in their decision-making processes.
They've voiced frustration by the lack of consistent comparable disclosure.
There's a number of investors that have specific impact investing funds or other sustainability
related investment funds and that trend is growing.
We've also seen pressure from shareholders that may not own a direct share but own through
like an exchange-traded fund or some funds similar to that where they'll use their proxy
vote as a way to voice their opinion and their concerns with a company's ESG performance.
We see particularly a lot of attention given to the ESG Raiders out there.
So like MSCI, it's seen a litix, ISS, CSR Hub.
These are organizations that are taking companies, environmental and social performance and governance
practices and basically putting out a report card on companies so that there's ratings
out there and companies can be compared to one another.
I think it really gets the attention of a lot of executives because I'm not sure that
many realize that that's out there and then all of a sudden they become aware of,
hey, some of these putting a report card out on my company but I got to know what that is
and what's the grounds for that score.
We see a lot of companies also getting questions from their customers.
Supply Chain is a very, very vast and broad thing and companies now are looking for more transparency
in their supply chains and so customers are putting the pressure on.
Particularly I would say you get a lot by the way of European companies where they are,
they're a little bit more advanced in this space because it's been something that's been reported
and companies have been doing it for longer there.
So they're just a bit more mature, I would say.
And now they're really raising the bar in terms of setting expectations for their customers
and what they expect in terms of environmental, social governance performance.
We also see the trends, I think you've probably heard a lot about the millennials
and the Gen Z generation but as consumers, their buying habits are a lot different than the
generations before them and the studies of surveys have showed that millennials are aligning their
purchasing power and their buying habits to their environmental and social beliefs too.
And so that's a more, I would say, more consumer facing companies feel that pressure.
And then lastly, I'm going to throw out regulation certainly here in the US,
any sort of strict regulation might be off the table with the current administration.
But you see states like California that have moved in the direction of regulation for environmental
reasons also I think significantly in the EU, the European Union's non-financial reporting
directive that recently went into effect that requires certain companies to report this information.
So there's a lot of drivers in this space and I think you could ask a lot of companies that are
in the market and you might find the various degree of answers in terms of why they're doing it or how they're doing it.
But at this point, I think it's really, these are business issues that companies have to face and
more and more of that's being recognized and companies don't want to be caught flat-footed
when looking at the risks and opportunities that relate to these topics.
Yeah, it's so interesting. I think it's such an exciting time to be alive and to be able to
witness this transformation that's occurring. And you know, one of the things I end up thinking
often about and talking some about is that sustainability really isn't only about us choosing to do good
relative to our communities, relative to the environment and so forth, but it is
increasingly becoming a question of competitive advantage. Oh, for sure.
Heidi of Industries, right? And as consumers are putting more and more pressure on as you're
describing as we're entering this age of increasing transparency, I am just so thrilled to know that
there is rapid transformation underway. And I'm curious, you're working with some of the
largest companies in the world, many mid-size mid-cap companies. What does that look like from your
vantage point right now? That's a good question. I would say it looks a lot like the Wild West.
As I said, absent any regulation anywhere outside of the EU's regulation.
Companies at this point right now in terms of reporting and disclosure can do really whatever they want.
I mean, there's no regulation in terms of what they have to report and how they have to report it.
There is, and there has been existing sustainability reporting standards. The Global
they've been around since the early 90s and it's the most widely used set of standards globally.
Used by many companies, I think there is a statistic out there that says at least in the US,
85% of the S&P 500 issue is sustainability report. The majority of those reports are in accordance with
the GRI standards. Additionally, just this month, yeah, we're still in November.
The sustainability accounting standards board just codified their standards. And they're
a bit different from GRI. So GRI standards are applicable to a very broad stakeholder group,
investors, customers, consumers, shareholders, employees, non-governmental organizations.
They're not necessarily industry specific. So, SASB, I think it was starting in about 2012,
undertook this mission to develop industry specific standards on the premise of financial
materiality. And with the idea and mind that these issues affect companies in a different manner.
For example, I always like to use the automotive industry as an example because when you talk about
GHG emissions, the biggest impact for automotive companies in particular is the use phase emissions.
So you and I driving around in our car versus a different manufacturer where they're not
their product is different and doesn't have the use phase emissions that automobiles do.
The SASB standards contemplate that. The SASB standards are specific to investors.
They're based on the concept of financial materiality. And so by disclosing these industry specific
standards, investors have a way to connect the ESG to the financial statements a little bit more
directly and kind of look at what is financially material.
That's really interesting. Well, I now have to ask, I should mention to your comments about
its November. So it's November while recording, but this may likely.
Oh, right. Okay. I guess December of 2018. So speaking of time travel,
I am struck when I'm building financial models for consulting clients and sometimes even
educating and tutoring business students around accounting. This is a very particular system.
You know, thanks to the Renaissance Italian merchant years ago. And it's a system that has evolved
to be very sophisticated, very specific in its application, which is now really used worldwide.
And it was developed initially and it has been used for centuries for financial
reporting and accounting specifically and has not been designed to take into account these other
things we would consider such as impacts on social well-being, impacts on environmental ecological
services, so on and so forth. And I have to ask you as you being a CPA, how does this leave you
after investing years and years in learning this sophisticated language and system?
How does this leave you feeling and thinking as the endeavor now is to incorporate more
information that is outside of the financial system strictly speaking?
No, that's another another great question and really, you know, if you look at the evolution
of financial accounting, it was an evolution. And I think that's what this is too. You know,
you have this is information that's out there in the public domain. And I always tell people that
really I spent eight years in the financial statement audit practice within the late before moving
into sustainability. And I always I look back on that time and I kind of take for granted my role
as the auditor because the systems were so established and the financial accounting rules are so
established and there's socks 404 and controls and you know everything was just very mature and
robust. And then you come into sustainability where you have companies with the ability to disclose
whatever they want, whenever they want, however they want. You know, there's for example, there's
even companies out there that they don't report in accordance with GRI or SASB. They'll make up their
own definition and report that definition. And and that's okay as long as the consumer of that
information has that definition. But I but I still think and you know, maybe this is the the auditor
in me coming out and and shining. But because this information is relied upon in the marketplace,
that it's it just speaks to the case for assurance and you know putting in place companies putting
in place those credible reporting processes and in controls specific to this subject matter and
engaging their financial statement auditor to perform assurance on this information. It's I think
critical in terms of where the market is at right now. There are many companies that do seek
assurance on maybe I'd say more so specific key performance indicators like most notably greenhouse
gas emissions. But not necessarily everything that they're reporting or their sustainability report
as a whole. And I think as this as this space matures and the reporting matures and the disclosure
matures, then we'll see the assurance of that follow as well. Yeah, it's really interesting to hear
that perspective. And one of the things I'm struck by in your earlier comment is the incredible
disparity that we're seeing state to state here in the United States with respect to regulation,
regulation, standard, and expectations. And it leaves me wondering you know on the on the one hand
many of these issues are related to risk obviously. And on the other hand many of these issues
are related to competitive advantage and economic development. And it leaves me thinking that you know
in some of the region, some of the states that are not really leading that are not really being
proactive around these issues. They're doing a double disservice to their communities potentially
where on the one hand, they're not addressing some of these risks we're facing as robustly as they
could be. And on the other hand, they're not driving the innovation in the laying the groundwork
for the competitive advantage and the eventual economic development that will ensue. And I'm just
curious if as you're looking at different firms all around the country, if you get a sense that
we're really seeing a situation where the ingredients for success over time are much more heavily
concentrated in certain areas and less so in other areas. There's definitely, I'd say an appetite
for innovation. And that's where I think the companies that are doing this whole space,
this whole sustainability thing, the ones that are doing it really right are the ones that are
the innovators and the ones that are able to take a downturn in the economy and gain market share.
Or do some really cool things in research and development and change their products such that it's
somehow game changing for the industry. There's a TED talk and it's a few years, probably at
least 10 years old now. Ray Anderson, the CEO of Interface Carpets, did this TED talk. It was called
the Business Logic for Sustainability. And in the TED talk, he takes you through the journey of
the company's sustainability thinking. And at one point in the TED talk, it pulls up a chart
and shows the economy and how the economy was moving. And there was this little dip in the economy.
And I think it was around 2000. But how his company was actually able to gain market share during that
time because of the way that they innovated their product and the sustainability trends that they
paid attention to and the things that they did in that respect. I think this is going to be
huge in the next 10 years. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change just issued a report
about a month or two ago now. And basically, it said that this climate change is worse than we thought.
And we're going to start seeing the impacts of climate change and a lot sooner than we thought.
So I think they mentioned like 2030 versus I think the previous reports were 2040 or 2050.
But then you start thinking, I'm like, gosh, well, I'm going to be around in 2030. And my kids
will definitely be around in 2030. And I think once businesses start maybe paying attention to that
a little bit more, they're going to recognize it's a little bit more sudden than expected. And
you know, kind of anticipating that through scenario analysis and risk planning. It's going to
give them a leg up when we do start seeing real climate change affecting our day to day lives.
And yes, yeah. And I think, you know, some of our friends who have experienced
coastal flooding and massive forest fires might already be feeling some of the early
of this climate change. And certainly the scientific community seems to be
pointing in that direction as well. And you know, I'm so happy you mentioned that,
that you have kids. And I love that in addition to being a sustainability professional, a CPA,
an accountant, you're also a mom. And you have two young children. And I'm curious as you're,
you know, working by day with all of these different companies that are in varying stages of
addressing and incorporating these sustainability values and standards. When you get home,
what is that like for you? And how do you see some of the sustainability opportunities or challenges
even on the home front? Well, I'll say this. I've already apologized to both of my sons
because the challenges that they'll face in their adult life in particular are much different
than the challenges that, you know, eye faces in adult particular when, you know, we start seeing
the impacts of climate change and, you know, that leading to food scarcity and things and things
like that. And I, as a parent, just have innate anxiety about that and, and hope that they will have
the answer. I've also started to brainwash them, if you will. If you ask my five-year-old son,
what water is, he'll tell you it's a scarce natural resource. And then, you know, I just try
in our everyday lives to do things and so that they're normal to my kids. For example,
both of my, both of my boys were in cloth diapers. We shovel our driveway instead of using a
snow blower. And in southeastern Wisconsin, that's quite a feat. Just earlier this week, I was
I was out in my driveway for four hours with the shovel after after a snow storm, but
we also have hobbies like I'm a beekeeper. I feel a couple of bee hives with my brother and have
like, have done, gotten him into that and, and my mom. And so that's a nice family activity and
something I feel strongly about. I have my kids, you know, all of this to my kids is just
something that's that they've grown up with and something that's normal. And I recognize that
society will start changing them the more and more that they are out of my purview and into
like school when they spend so much time with school and their friends. And so I'm trying now,
while they're really, really young to to put my influence on them that this is something that's
super important and something that they're going to they're going to be challenged with as
they grow into adults. So yes, well, it's so it's so wonderful how proactive you're being with them
and that you're not only on the one hand teaching them about things like water, fresh water being a
scarce and precious resource. On the other hand, you're demonstrating ways that we can be proactive
in our own homes, our own yards, our own neighborhoods. And of course, with the why on earth community,
we are increasingly doing work all around the country with some of the very hopeful activities we
can do such as soil building, which really can help to reverse the climate change trends,
really help to stabilize climate by sequestering carbon. And my sincere hope is that our kids and
all of us in the next several years and decades are going to engage deeply in some of these restorative
and regenerative practices. And my sense is that we'll see companies small medium and large,
increasingly engaging in some of these community activities as a way to market and advertise and
you know, live streaming media has become very big. And I'm just I'm thrilled to think that we can
really mobilize so much hope and the business community can take such a strong leadership position
around all of this. And as we're facing these challenges, they can be overwhelming and daunting.
There yeah, there are you know, to that point, there are so many companies out there that do a lot
and and make a really big impact. And unfortunately, they don't they don't tell that story, they don't
say that. And and that's I feel one of the really cool parts of my job is I get to go into
into all of these different companies and all of these in different industries. And I get to hear
about everything they're doing and it and it really gives me makes me feel optimistic in a
in a time when it's very easy not to be optimistic. Just some of the cool things that are being done
and the things that exist out there and how they're how they're innovating and what they're
doing to address, you know, challenges like soil degradation and erosion and anything waste.
And so that's it's really refreshing. So there's a there's a lot more that I think that's being done
that's just not out there in in the public. And I wish I wish companies would some would sometimes
tell tell those really cool stories. But you know, my sense is that we might be seeing a whole
lot more of that. And I often joke with my media partner, Artem Nicolcov from Earth Coast Productions
about how sometimes the the letters CSO stand for Chief Sustainability Officer and sometimes they
stand for Chief Streaming Officer. We talk often about how we're seeing this convergence where
companies of all sizes can increasingly share these stories, tell these stories and of course that's
very potent in social media. It's very potent in some of the new ways of marketing and advertising
and messaging. And my goodness, that could be such a potent additional way to mobilize this kind
of positive action in our communities all over and that gives me hope. Yeah, and I think you'll see
that. You know, you've got the millennial generation now getting older and sort of creeping
their way into upper management. And this is just this is just the millennial thinking and this is
how they do business. And that's that's different from previous generations. And so I definitely think
those those facets of their lives is going to be it's going to be really apparent when you start
seeing them as CEOs and executives and board members. You know, the board plays a huge role in this.
And I would say a lot of boards might be a bit skeptical at first, but just as in it isn't
anything, I think once you learn more of the subject matter and in what this is all about, it just
the dollars and cents just makes sense. Absolutely. I want to pick up your comment about the

I just want to mention to our audience that this is the why on earth communities stewardship and

I think it's gotten tremendous attention actually. I think the you know oftentimes we think about

extend to the board. But they play a critical role as more and more
particularly in where we are in this world in terms of climate change. The the measurement

a very broad topic. And so that sometimes makes it difficult for for boards to hone in on specific
